subsection.title: Summary of Power Functions
subsection.p: A Power Function is a single-term function of the form y = ax^k where a and k are constant numbers.
For us, the important characteristic of a power function is the shape of its graph, and in particular, the tendency of the graph as x gets very far from zero.

Power functions of the form y = x^k when k is an even number (2, 4, 6, \cdots), all resemble x^2, in the sense that their output values constantly increase as x \rightarrow \infty or x \rightarrow -\infty.

Power functions of the form y = x^k when k is an odd number (1, 3, 5, \cdots), all resemble y = x, in the sense that their output values constantly increase as x \rightarrow \infty, and they decrease as x \rightarrow -\infty.

subsection.title: Summary of Polynomials
subsection.p: Polynomials are functions of the form: y = a_nx^n + a_{n−1}x^{n−1} + \cdots + a_1x + a_0 where the numbers a_0, a_1, \cdots, a_{n-1}, a_n are some constant real numbers, called coefficients.
Note that some of the coefficients may be zero.

remark.p: It is common to write a list of unknown constants like a_1, a_2, \cdots, a_n when we don't know how large n is. This just means that there is some finite number of these constants.

subsection.p:
While this may look complicated, here are some examples you already know:
\text{The line } y = 3x - 7 \text{The parabola } y = x^2 + 1
The degree of a polynomial is the value of highest exponent in the formula.
So our parabola y = x^2 + 1 has degree 2 and our line y = 3x − 7 has degree 1.

The coefficients can be positive, negative or zero. In the 4^{\rm{th}} degree polynomial
y \amp= −5x^4+2x^3−x^1+0.69x^0 \amp= -5x^4 + 2x^3 - x + 0.69
the coefficient of x^3 is 2, and the coefficient of x^2 is 0 (because there is no x^2 term).
The term with the highest power of x is called the leading term. In the polynomial above, the leading term is -5x^4.
When polynomials are multiplied together, the new formula is also a polynomial, and the degree of the new polynomial is just the sum of the degrees of the formulas you multiplied together.

example.p: The two linear (1^{\rm{st}} degree) polynomials 7x + 2 and 5x + 4 will create a 2^{\rm{nd}} degree polynomial when multiplied together:

Recall from chapter, that if we named the linear functions f(x) = 7x + 2 and g(x) = 5x + 4, then the 2^{\rm{nd}} degree polynomial 35x^2 + 38x + 8 may be thought of as the function combination: f(x)\cdot g(x)

subsection.p: An input value which gives an output of zero is called a root of the polynomial, and a root corresponds to an x-intercept of polynomial's graph.

example.p: The values x \amp= 3 x \amp= \frac{1}{2} x \amp= -4 are all roots of the polynomial: f(x) = 8x^3 + 4x^2 - 100x + 48

subsection.p: If you know the roots of a polynomial, you can create linear factors (lines of degree 1) which have those same roots. Multiplying those linear factors together will create a polynomial which has all of those roots.

example.p: In Example, we were told that the polynomial had the roots 3, \frac{1}{2} and -4.
If we wanted to write the formula for f(x), using only this information, we could create the linear factors: (x - 3) (x - \frac{1}{2}) (x + 4)
Multiplying these factors together (x-3)(x-\frac{1}{2})(x+4) gives a polynomial which has all three of those roots.
Note: This polynomial is not the same as f(x) from Example, though it has the same roots.

subsection.p: Now, beyond just making a polynomial have particular roots, you can also vertically stretch or compress your function in order to adjust the shape, making it pass through any other point you may know on the polynomial.

example.p:
Suppose we know that a polynomial f(x) has the roots
x \amp= 5 x \amp= -6 x \amp= 9
and that it also contains the point (4,2).

We can determine a polynomial which has these characteristics by creating linear factors which have the given roots:
x = 5 \amp\implies (x - 5) x = -6 \amp\implies (x + 6) x = 9 \amp\implies (x - 9)

Multiplying these factors together will make a polynomial which has the given roots: y = (x-5)(x+6)(x-9) However, it does not pass through the point (4, 2), because using the input x = 4 gives:
y \amp= (4-5)(4+6)(4-9) \amp= (-1)(10)(-5) \amp= 50

In order to make our polynomial also pass through the point (4,2), we will use a vertical compression. We know this must be a compression, because our function currently has an output of 50 when the input is 4 — we want the output to be only 2.
For the vertical compression, we include a constant factor k to our function: y = k(x-5)(x+6)(x-9)
Notice that multiplying by a constant k does not change the roots of the function.

In order to determine the value of k that will work here, we use the point (4,2), substituting 4 for x, and 2 for y:
2 \amp= k(4-5)(4+6)(4-9) 2 \amp= k(50) k \amp= \frac{2}{50} \amp=0.04
Therefore, we have a polynomial which passes through (4,2) and has the correct roots:y = 0.04(x-5)(x+6)(x-9)

remark.p: This is not the only polynomial that fits these conditions. Why?

subsection.p: Linear factors may be repeated, as in: y = (x-3)^2 and y = x(x+1)^2(x-6)^4
Since a linear factor (x-a) corresponds to a root x = a, then repeating a linear factor will give us a repeated root.
If a root is repeated k times, then we say that root has multiplicity k.

example.p: The polynomial y = x^3(x-5)^2 has only two roots: x = 0 and x = 5
We say the root x = 0 has multiplicity 3, and the root x = 5 has multiplicity 2.

subsection.p: How does a repeated root change the graph? We know that a root will appear as an x-intercept on the graph, but will repeating a root in a formula mean the x-intercept is somehow also repeated?
Each of these parabolas has just one root which has been repeated twice, and the parabolas appear to bounce off of the x-axis at their roots.
This phenomenon of bouncing remains a characteristic of the graph, even if we give a polynomial more linear factors, such as: y = (x+4)^2(x-1)
